column4: Mother whose 11-year-old son died in Texas freeze sues for $100 million
column5: (Reuters) - The mother of an 11-year-old boy who died after they lost electricity and heat in their Texas mobile home during last week’s freeze has filed a $100 million lawsuit against two power companies for gross negligence.
column6: Maria Pineda said the Electric Reliability Council of Texas (ERCOT) and Entergy Corp are responsible for the death of her son Cristian, who was found unresponsive on the morning of Feb. 16 at home, where he shared a bed with his 3-year-old brother.
column7: More than 4 million people in Texas lost power and at least two dozen people died after a snowstorm blanketed the state last week and sent temperatures plunging well below freezing.
column8: The complaint filed on Saturday accused the defendants of ignoring a Federal Energy Regulatory Commission recommendation following a 2011 freeze to “winterize” the power grid, and were caught “wholly unprepared” when the grid failed last week.
column9: Cristian froze to death “because grid wasn’t a priority, and the energy provider made decisions based on profits,” said the complaint filed in the Jefferson County District Court.
column10: The family lives in Conroe, Texas, a Houston suburb.
column11: ERCOT, a cooperative responsible for about 90% of Texas’ electricity, said it will respond “accordingly” after reviewing the lawsuit.
column12: Entergy declined to discuss the lawsuit, but a spokesman said it was “deeply saddened by the loss of life.”
column13: Pineda’s lawyer Tony Buzbee told ABC News he represents seven families who suffered deaths in the storm’s aftermath, and more lawsuits against power companies are planned. An autopsy on Cristian is being performed, ABC News said.
column14: ERCOT began rolling blackouts on Feb. 15, saying they were needed to avert a cascading, statewide outage.
column15: “We are confident that our grid operators made the right choice,” ERCOT said on Monday.
column16: President Joe Biden approved a major disaster declaration for Texas on Saturday.
column17: Texas has an unusual, deregulated energy market that lets it avoid federal regulation but limits its ability to draw emergency power from other grids.

column4: Entergy Corp says power restored for customers affected by Texas cold
column5: Feb 21 (Reuters) - Entergy Corp said on Sunday that its Texas unit has completed the restoration of power for all customers affected by the past week’s winter storms.
column6: "As of Saturday morning, Entergy Texas, Inc. has restored all customers affected by this week's winter storms", the company said in a statement bit.ly/2MbhlYW late on Sunday. (Reporting by Kanishka Singh in Bengaluru; Editing by Christian Schmollinger)

column4: Entergy Corp says additional outages occurring as Delta moves north
column5: (Reuters) - Electric power producer Entergy Corp ETR.N said on Saturday that additional power outages were occurring as Delta moved north through Mississippi.
column6: “As of this morning, 495,000 power outages amassed throughout Entergy’s service territories,” the company said in a statement on Saturday.
column7: Hundreds of thousands of residents were left without power after Delta made landfall as a Category 2 hurricane on Friday. By midday on Saturday, it had weakened to a tropical depression.

column4: Entergy defeats ADA suit by nuke plant guard with Chronic Fatigue Syndrome – 1st Circuit
column5: Entergy Nuclear Operations did not violate the Americans with Disabilities Act by firing an armed security guard who waited more than two years to disclose that he suffered from Chronic Fatigue Syndrome, a federal appeals court held Monday.
column6: The 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed a ruling by a federal judge in Massachusetts, who granted Entergy’s motion for summary judgment last year after finding that Iraq War veteran Mark Flaherty had offered no admissible evidence to show that he was fired in 2015 as a result of disability discrimination.

column4: Entergy dispatchers were supervisors, says NLRB
column5: The National Labor Relations Board has ruled that dispatchers for a unit of electrical company Entergy Corp in Mississippi were supervisors who cannot unionize, in a long-running case that was sent back to the board by a U.S. appeals court.
column6: A unanimous three-member board panel on Thursday said that because the dispatchers organized by an International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers local used independent judgment in assigning field workers to address power outages, they were supervisors under the National Labor Relations Act. The law allows only rank-and-file employees to unionize.
